Description: Flat limestone figure rudimentarily carved, with a slightly convex body in front, roughly squared on the sides, back and underside, sloping shoulders attached to a large round flat head without neck and a sloping ledge at the bottom of the figure's front indicating the feet.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, Findspot 51, domestic buildings in the urban area to the east of the Saite enclosure (so-called "Camp").
Curator's comments: See W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 71-72 § 68 : "Stone idol"; "The stone figure (3) is of the rudest type possible, without limbs or features; were it not for a ledge representing the feet, it might be also doubted if it were not a loom weight, with a notch to tie a string in". The Findspot number 51 is scratched on the back, under the left shoulder.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 61 § 58, p. 71-72 § 68, pl. xxiv, 3)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.44, p.58, p.178, pl.20)
Condition: surface flaking on the top the head an the left shoulder
